DeregistrationReasonOtherText: we no longer lease the property/tank

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Program Executive Summary



CHS is dedicated to preventing accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. The company stores and

distributes anhydrous ammonia in pressure vessels.



CHS believes that the health, safety, and preservation of our environment are critical components of effective

management and business success. As a company, we are committed to:



-Providing a secure and health conscious work environment for employees and visitors

-Conducting our business with always having value for the communities in which we operate and in the spirit

of a good neighbor

-Meeting or exceeding the requirements of the environmental, health, & safety laws and regulations

-Training employees on the environmental, health & safety requirements of their jobs

-Working with government and other stakeholders to identify and solve problems



Anhydrous ammonia is stored in pressure vessels on properties. It is transferred into the vessel from either

semi-transports or rail cars and then placed into application equipment or nurse tanks. The application

equipment and/or nurse tanks are then transported to the farmer's field where the anhydrous ammonia is

injected into the soil.



An anhydrous ammonia storage tank is equipped with safety relief valves that are designed to release

pressure in the event the tank becomes over pressurized. The tanks are also equipped with excessive flow

valves that are designed to shut down the flow of ammonia if a sudden release should happen.

The worst-case release scenario is created to show how far a plume of ammonia with a concentration greater

than 200 parts per million (PPM) would travel before being dispersed to a safe exposure level.

A complete discharge of the storage vessel would be a very unusual event. We are also required to create an

alternative or more likely release event. Although we will continue to do what we can to ensure no

accidental release occurs, we have chosen a 2-inch pipe or hose rupture to me

et this requirement. Again,

calculations show the extent of the plume with an ammonia concentration greater than 200 PPM.



We have used RMP Comp to calculate the area these types of releases would impact. RMP Comp is supplied

to us by the EPA. It tends to over exaggerate the plume, which in turn adds a good safety factor into the

planning process. Our written programs are continually updated and are available for review at the ammonia

storage locations.



In the event of a release from a storage facility that could impact the community, we advise those in the

affected area to shelter in place until the plume dissipates. Shelter in place involves everyone in the affected

area seeking shelter indoors, shutting the windows and turning off the air conditioning and other ventilation

systems.



CHS operates over 130 storage sites across the country. In the past five years we have had very few releases

from fixed storage facilities. Vandalism and theft from nurse tanks has accounted for the some of our

releases.



Our employees are trained in the characteristics and proper handling procedures for anhydrous ammonia.

They are equipped with the proper personal protective equipment for routine handling of the product. The

training also covers the basics in responding to emergencies involving ammonia releases and is available to

assist the community first responders with technical information and advice.



CHS provide training, training material and emergency response information to each fire department with

jurisdiction over our locations. We also meet with concerned citizens and other interested parties about our

risk management program and anhydrous ammonia safety in general.



CHS continually updates the training provided to its employees. Employees are trained in proper handling,

facility inspections, ammonia characteristics; emergency procedures and must review the emergency

response plan, emergency action plan, and site security plan annually.



C

HS is proud of its past safety performance and is continuing to look for new ways to improve its anhydrous

ammonia safety program.
